title: K-64 (Kansas highway)
text:
K-64 was a <a href="state%20highway">state highway</a> in <a href="Pratt%20County%2C%20Kansas">Pratt County</a>, <a href="Kansas">Kansas</a>. The highway was a partial bypass of <a href="Pratt%2C%20Kansas">Pratt</a> that ran from <a href="U.S.%20Route%20281%20in%20Kansas">U.S. Route 281</a> (US-281) just south of the city limits to <a href="U.S.%20Route%2054%20in%20Kansas">US-54</a> and <a href="U.S.%20Route%20400%20in%20Kansas">US-400</a> east of them. The route was maintained by the <a href="Kansas%20Department%20of%20Transportation">Kansas Department of Transportation</a> until July 10, 2015 when the road was turned over to Pratt County. K-64 was not part of the <a href="National%20Highway%20System%20%28United%20States%29">National Highway System</a>.
Before state highways were numbered in Kansas there were <a href="auto%20trail">auto trail</a>s. The eastern terminus follows the former Cannon Ball Route and Atlantic and Pacific Highway. K-64 was designated around 1932, and paved in 1937. It was decommissioned July 10, 2015, after the Kansas Department of Transportation expanded several miles of US-54 and US-400 east of Pratt to four lanes. In exchange for the expansion, Pratt County agreed to take control of K-64.
Route description.
K-64 began at an intersection with <a href="U.S.%20Route%20281%20in%20Kansas">US-281</a> just south of <a href="Pratt%2C%20Kansas">Pratt</a>. The highway went east on a two-lane road through a hilly, slightly wooded area. The road passed south of an unnamed lake, then turned to the north. The route then crossed the south fork of the <a href="Ninnescah%20River">Ninnescah River</a> and the <a href="Kansas%20and%20Oklahoma%20Railroad">Kansas and Oklahoma Railroad</a> before reaching its northern terminus at a <a href="T%20intersection">T intersection</a> with <a href="U.S.%20Route%2054%20in%20Kansas">US-54</a> and <a href="U.S.%20Route%20400">US-400</a>.
K-64 was maintained by the <a href="Kansas%20Department%20of%20Transportation">Kansas Department of Transportation</a> (KDOT). In 2012, the traffic on the route, calculated in <a href="annual%20average%20daily%20traffic">annual average daily traffic</a>, was 750 vehicles per day on the north–south section and 1260 vehicles per day on the east–west section. K-64 was not a part of the <a href="National%20Highway%20System%20%28United%20States%29">National Highway System</a>, which is a system of highways considered important to the nation's defense, economy, and mobility. K-64 did connect to the National Highway System at its eastern terminus.
History.
Prior to the formation of the Kansas state highway system, there were <a href="auto%20trail">auto trail</a>s, which were an informal network of marked routes that existed in the United States and <a href="Canada">Canada</a> in the early part of the 20th century. The eastern terminus follows the former Cannon Ball Route and Atlantic and Pacific Highway.
K-64 was designated by 1932, and at that time extended from K-8 east then north to US-54. Then between July 1938 and 1940, K-8 was renumbered to US-281. The route was paved with an oil surface in 1937, and it had not changed until it was decommissioned. K-64 was decommissioned on July 10, 2015, after KDOT had expanded several miles of US-54 and US-400 east of Pratt to four lanes. After the expansion, Pratt County agreed to take control of K-64.
